lines.text: My time with you is at an end, Ebenezer Scrooge. Will you profit from what I've shown you of the good in most men's hearts?
I don't know, how can I promise!
If it's too hard a lesson for you to learn, then learn this lesson!
[opens his robe, revealing two starving children]

[shocked]
Spirit, are these yours?
They are Man's. This boy is Ignorance, this girl is Want. Beware them both, but most of all, beware this boy!
But have they no refuge, no resource?

[quoting Scrooge]
Are there no prisons? Are there no workhouses?
At this festive time of year, Mr. Scrooge, it is more than usually desirable that we should make some slight provision for the poor and destitute.
Are there no prisons?
Plenty of prisons.
And the union workhouses - are they still in operation?
They are. I wish I could say they were not.
Oh, from what you said at first I was afraid that something had happened to stop them in their useful course. I'm very glad to hear it.
I don't think you quite understand us, sir. A few of us are endeavoring to buy the poor some meat and drink, and means of warmth.
Why?
Because it is at Christmastime that want is most keenly felt, and abundance rejoices. Now what can I put you down for?
Huh! Nothing!
You wish to be anonymous?

[firmly, but calmly]
I wish to be left alone. Since you ask me what I wish sir, that is my answer. I help to support the establishments I have named; those who are badly off must go there.
Many can't go there.
And some would rather die.
I wear the chain I forged in life! I made it link by link and yard by yard! I gartered it on of my own free will and by my own free will, I wore it!
Who are you?
Ask me who I was.
All right, all right, who WERE you then?
In life, I was your partner, Jacob Marley.
Well, in that case, CAN you sit down?
I can.
But it was only that you were an honest man of business!
BUSINESS? Mankind was my business! Their common welfare was my business!
Your sister was always a delicate creature, of whom a breath might have withered, but she had a large heart.
She had.
She dies a married woman and had, I think, children.
One child.
Your nephew.
She died giving him life.
As your mother died giving you life, for which your father never forgave you, as if you were to blame.
You have my sympathy.
Ah! You do not know the weight and length of strong chain you bear yourself! It was as full and as long as this seven Christmas eves ago and you have labored on it since. Ah, it is a ponderous chain!
Bob's yer uncle Mr. Scrooge!
Through the window?
Are you afraid?
Well... I am a mortal, and liable to fall.
Bear but a touch of my hand, and you will be upheld in more than this.
Mr. Scrooge?
I'm busy.
Well, it's about Mr. Marley, sir! He's dying!
Well, what do you want me to do about it? If he's dying, he's dying.
You see that toothpick?
I do.
But you're not looking at it!
Yet I see it, notwithstanding.
Well, then, I'll just swallow this and be tortured by a legion of hobgoblins, all of my own creation! It's all HUMBUG, I tell you, HUMBUG!
Are you all right, Mr. Scrooge?

[ecstatic]
I... I don't know. I don't know anything. I never did know anything.
[starts laughing]
But now I KNOW that I don't know anything!
[begins to sing and clap his hands]
I don't know anything!/ I never did know anything!/ But now I know that I don't know/ All on a Christmas morning!
[speaking again]
Shall I stand on my head? I must stand on my head.
[He does so, and Mrs. Dilber runs out screaming]
A guinea? For me? What for?
I'll give you a guess!

[pause]
To keep me mouth shut?
Look to see me no more. But look here, that you may remember for your own sake what has passed between us!
Why do they lament?
They seek to interfere for good in human matters, and have lost their power forever.

[to Bob Cratchit]
I've come to say that Mister Marley ain't expected to make it through the night, and that if Mister Scrooge wishes to take his leave of him, he'd best nip along sharply, or there won't be no Mister Marley to take leave of, as we know the use of the word. He's breathing very queer - when he does breathe at all.
Waiter! More bread.
Ha'penny extra, sir.

[pauses]
No more bread.
You've never seen the like of me before, have you?
Never, and I wish the pleasure had been indefinitely postponed.
Merry Christmas, Mr. Scrooge! In keeping with the situation!
What is your business here?
Your welfare.
My welfare?
Your reclamation, then. Take heed, rise, and walk with me.

[of Jacob Marley]
Is he dead?
Yes.

[to the undertaker]
It's just like you said!
I always know.

[to himself, laughing]
A merry Christmas, Ebenezer! You old HUMBUG! Oh, and a happy new year! As if you deserved it!
And as your business prospered, Ebenezer Scrooge, a golden idol took possession of your heart, as Alice said it would.

[to Fred's wife]
Can you forgive a pig-headed old fool with no eyes to see with and no ears to hear with all these years?
Bob, I haven't taken leave of my senses. I've come to them.
What do you want with me?
Much.

It is required of every man that the spirit within him should walk abroad among his fellow men! If it goes not forth in life, it is condemned to do so after death! It is doomed to wander through the world! Oh, woe is me! And witness what it cannot share but MIGHT HAVE SHARED on Earth and turned to happiness!

[to the Spirit of Christmas Yet To Come]
I am standing in the presence of the Spirit of Christmas Yet To Come? And you're going to show me the shadows of things that have not yet happened but will happen? Spirit of the Future, I fear you more than any spectre I have met tonight! But even in my fear, I must say that I am too old! I cannot change! I cannot! It's not that I'm inpenitent, it's just... Wouldn't it be better if I just went home to bed?
[pause]
No? Well, very well. Lead on.

[to Bob Cratchit]
Well, my friend, I'm not going to beat around the bush. I'm simply not going to stand this sort of thing any longer. Which leaves me no choice, but to raise your salary.
[starts laughing hysterically]

[Giggling]
No. Mrs. Dilber - I'm not mad.
[He ruffles his hair so that it looks wild]
Even if I look it!

[about Scrooge and Marley]
In short, gentlemen, if you want to save the fair name of the company by accepting their generous offer, they become the company!

[grumpily]
I don't deserve to be so happy.
[starts laughing uncontrollably again]
I can't help it!
I must have a label... label label label label label!

[Scrooge raises her pay from 2 shillings a week to 16]
Do you want to see a doctor?
A doctor? Certainly not, nor the undertaker!
I'll send it to Bob Cratchit, and he shan't know who sent it. It's twice the size of Tiny Tim!

[singing]
I don't know anything, I never did know anything, but now I know that I don't know, all on a Christmas morning.
Are you the spirit whose coming was foretold to me?
I am.
Who and what are you?
I am the Ghost of Christmas Past.
Long past?
No, your past.
In life, my spirit never rose beyond the limits of our money-changing holes! Now I am doomed to wander without rest or peace, incessant torture and remorse!
But it was only that you were a good man of business, Jacob!
BUSINESS? Mankind was my business! Their common welfare was my business! And it is at this time of the rolling year that I suffer most!
Come in! Come in, and know me better, man!
You'll want the whole day off tomorrow, I suppose.
If quite convenient, sir.
It's not convenient. And it's not fair! If I stopped you half a crown for it, you'd think yourself ill used, wouldn't you? But you don't think me ill used if I pay a day's wages for now work, hmm?
'Tis only once a year, sir.
That's a poor excuse for picking a man's pocket every 25th of December.
Yes, sir. I'm sure I'm very sorry, sir, to cause you such an inconvenience. It's the family more than me, sir. They put their hearts into Christmas as it were, sir.
Yes, and put their hands into my pockets as it were, sir. I suppose you'd better have the whole day. But be back all the earlier the next morning.
I will indeed, sir. Thank you, sir! It's more than generous of you, sir.
Yes, I know it is, you don't have to tell me.
Who is that? The doctor?
The undertaker.
You don't believe in letting the grass grow under your feet, do you?
Ours is a very competitive profession, sir.

[to the Spirit of Christmas Yet To Come]
Before I draw nearer to that stone, tell me! Are these the shadows of things that must be, or are they the shadows of things that MIGHT be?
May you be happy in the life you've chosen.

[angrily]
Thank you! I shall be!
So! Is your heart still unmoved towards us, then?
I'm too old and beyond hope! Go and redeem some younger, more promising creature, and leave me to keep Christmas in my own way!

Mortal! We Spirits of Christmas do not live only one day of our year. We live the whole three-hundred and sixty-five. So is it true of the Child born in Bethlehem. He does not live in men's hearts one day of the year, but in all days of the year. You have chosen not to seek Him in your heart. Therefore, you will come with me and seek Him in the hearts of men of good will.

[to Scrooge]
Alice. The same Alice you had sworn to love for all eternity. She is not changed by the harshness of the world, but you are.
Are you more rested?
I am. Bless your dear, gentle heart. You know, I didn't think there was anyone like you left in the whole wide world.

[at a homeless shelter where Alice is working]
Spirit, are these people real, or are they shadows?
They are real. We are the shadows.
Both of us?
Did you not cut yourself off from you fellow man when you lost the love of that delicate creature?

[as Marley lies on his death bed]
Well, Jacob! Have they seen to you properly? Last rites and such?
[Marley nods]
There's nothing i can do?
[Marley nods again]
Oh? What, particularly?

[rasping]
While... there's still time...
Time? Time for what?

[rasping]
Wrong... we were wrong.
Wrong? Well, we can't be right all the time , can we? Nobody's perfect. You mustn't reproach yourself, Jacob. We've been no worse than the next man, or no better if it comes to that.

[rasping]
Save... yourself.
Save myself? Save myself from what?
[Marley breathes his last]
Speak...!
[pauses as he realizes Marley is dead]
Go, and redeem some other promising young creature, but leave me to keep Christmas in my own way.
God bless us, every one!
I don't deserve to be so happy.
[laughing]
But I can't help it.
[laughs and throws his pen away]
I-I I just can't help it.
